choices.text: Perform a lumbar puncture 6 hours after the onset of headache

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady is having a sudden onset of severe headache. She described it as the worst headache of her life. It came on with a 'bang'. A CT scan of the brain is reported as normal. There are no neurological signs on examination. The next best management step is to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For the diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage in a patient with normal CT, lumbar puncture is usually performed at least 6 hours (ideally 12 hours) after the onset of symptoms. This allows red blood cell breakdown products to accumulate, reducing false-negative results from early sampling.
  • The CSF specimen should be examined by spectrophotometry for the presence of xanthochromia due to the presence of oxyhaemoglobin and bilirubin.
  • Lysis of the red blood cells and subsequent conversion of haemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6-12 h. This xanthochromic spinal fluid peaks in intensity at 48 h and lasts for 1- 4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.

Explanation of Other Options:

Start ergotamine (Option A): Ergotamine treats migraine and is contraindicated in suspected haemorrhage.

MRI of the brain (Option B): MRI lacks the rapid sensitivity of CT in acute SAH and isn't indicated when CT is normal, but suspicion remains.

Perform a lumbar puncture immediately (Option C): Sampling too early may miss xanthochromia before haemoglobin breakdown, yielding false negatives.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man complains of pain in the right eye, which has worsened over the last few days. On examination, he had a ptosis of the right eye. He also had a weakness of superior upgaze of the right eye and loss of accommodation reflex, with a dilated pupil. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Complete Ptosis of the right eye with loss of accommodation reflex indicates a 3rd nerve palsy.

  • Patients with painful, isolated third nerve palsy with pupillary involvement are most likely due to a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Other causes of mononeuritis multiplex (diabetes, vasculitis, syphilis) can also cause a third nerve palsy, but are seldom painful.
  • Loss of accommodation reflex reflects parasympathetic fibre compression on the nerve periphery, supporting a compressive aetiology rather than a demyelinating or neuromuscular junction disorder.

Arteriogram - Lateral view showing a posterior communicating artery aneurysm.

Explanation of Other Options:

Myasthenia gravis (Option A): Myasthenia gravis would cause diurnal symptoms of ptosis and diplopia, which would occur a few hours after waking up.

Neurosyphilis (Option B): Neurosyphilis would cause an Argyll Robertson Pupil, which is characterised by absent pupillary reflex with a preserved accommodation reflex. It occurs due to a lesion in the pretectal region.

Multiple sclerosis (Option C): Multiple sclerosis would cause an internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which causes a loss of adduction of the ipsilateral eye on abduction of the contralateral eye. It occurs due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man complained of a severe headache. Following this, he developed nausea and vomiting and came to the ER to be assessed. A CT scan demonstrated blood in the left sylvian fissure. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A sudden "thunderclap" headache with CT showing blood in the sylvian fissure is classic for aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage, most commonly due to ruptured saccular (berry) aneurysms.
  • Berry aneurysms arise at arterial bifurcations in the circle of Willis and, when they rupture, spill arterial blood into the subarachnoid space, pooling in fissures and cisterns.
  • The accompanying nausea and vomiting result from meningeal irritation and an abrupt rise in intracranial pressure, supporting the diagnosis of SAH from aneurysm rupture.
  • Berry aneurysms are associated with conditions such as autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which increases rupture risk.

Explanation of Other Options:

Migraine (Option A): Migraines produce severe headache without intracranial bleeding and would not show blood on CT.

Subdural haematoma (Option B): SDH appears as a crescentic collection along the cerebral convexity from venous bleeding, not localised to the sylvian fissure.

Carotid dissection (Option C): Dissection causes ischemic symptoms (stroke, neck pain) rather than subarachnoid haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with speech difficulty. He has difficulty with word identification and repetition. He can pick out correct objects when instructed to do so and is not confused. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is having aphasia, since he has difficulty with word identification (anomia). His comprehension is normal, hence Wenicke's area is normal. So he is likely suffering from Broca's Aphasia.

A patient with Wernicke's Aphasia may look confused to the examiner because of the neologisms and increased word output. Repetition will be lost in all aphasias except transcortical motor aphasia, transcortical sensory aphasia, pure anomia and pure alexia.

  • Broca's Area (Inferior frontal lobe) damage causes impaired fluency, intact comprehension, impaired repetition [expressive dysphasia].
  • Wernicke's Area (posterior, superior temporal lobe) damage causes normal fluency, impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition [receptive dysphasia]. (Option C)

Superior frontal lobe (Option A): Lesions here affect supplementary motor functions and may cause akinetic mutism but do not produce the classic expressive aphasia pattern.

Medial superior temporal lobe (Option B): Damage in this region might impair auditory processing or transcortical sensory function but spares expressive language and comprehension in a different way.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a sudden and severe episode of headache. No precipitating factor was identified. Except for mild neck stiffness, general physical and neurological examinations were unremarkable. On admission, a computed tomography (CT) scan showed a thin collection of blood on the right sylvian cistern, establishing the diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The admitting doctor is considering further management. Which of the following medications has been shown to decrease the incidence of cerebral infarction in patients with subarachnoid haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medical management of SAH focuses on protecting the airway, managing blood pressure before and after aneurysm treatment, preventing rebleeding before treatment, managing vasospasm and Delayed Cerebral Ischemia (DCI), treating hydrocephalus, treating hyponatremia, limiting secondary brain insults, and preventing pulmonary embolus (PE).

DCI remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality following aneurysmal SAH. Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, perhaps by preventing ischemic injury rather than reducing the risk of vasospasm.

Vasopressors and hydration also help to prevent cerebral ischemia.

Amlodipine lacks evidence for benefit in SAH and is not recommended for DCI prevention. (Option A)

Osmotic agents can worsen cerebral perfusion and worsen ischemia and hence should be given only to those with features of raised ICP. (Option D)

Steroids may be used to reduce head and neck pain caused by blood in the subarachnoid space. They do not reduce cerebral ischemia and are hence not routinely recommended. (Option B)

So the most appropriate answer is Nimodipine.

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese woman presents with a gradual onset of severe headache and visual blurring. On examination, she has bilateral papilledema, without any focal deficits or seizures. Which of the following may help improve the condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A chronic headache with papilledema can occur with an intracranial space-occupying lesion (ICSOL) or idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Given the presence of obesity and the absence of focal deficits or seizures, the possibility of IIH should be considered.

  • Vitamin A, prednisolone, minocycline and cyclosporin make idiopathic intracranial hypertension (used to be known as benign intracranial hypertension worse.
  • Acetazolamide is used to treat idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). IIH is likely to be due to high pressure caused by the buildup or poor absorption of cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain. The disorder is most common in women between the ages of 20 and 50. Symptoms include headache, nausea, vomiting, and pulsating intracranial noises, closely mimicking symptoms of brain tumours.
  • Acetazolamide may be used in vasogenic oedema due to tumours.

Explanation of Other Options:

Vitamin A (Option A): Excess vitamin A is a known risk factor for IIH and can exacerbate intracranial pressure.

Prednisolone (Option B): Corticosteroids may cause fluid retention and weight gain, worsening intracranial hypertension; not recommended.

Minocycline (Option C): Tetracycline antibiotics, including minocycline, can precipitate or aggravate IIH.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the hospital having collapsed to the ground suddenly and was unable to move his left leg and arm. There was no loss of consciousness. He has a past medical history of hypertension only. The episode lasted a few seconds, and he has been relatively well. Examination reveals a mild hemiparesis of the left arm and leg. Which is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pure motor weakness of the face, arm, and leg without cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, visual field defects) indicates a lacunar syndrome, classically due to a small infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
  • Lacunar infarcts result from lipohyalinosis of penetrating arteries in hypertensive patients, producing small, rounded lesions and often presenting with transient or mild persistent deficits.
  • Imaging with MRI diffusion-weighted sequences typically reveals a small (<15 mm) hyperintense focus in the internal capsule corresponding to the site of infarction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pontine haemorrhage (Option A): Pontine bleeds cause altered consciousness, pinpoint pupils, quadriparesis, and often "locked-in" syndrome.

Primary epilepsy (Option B): Seizure-related Todd's paralysis follows convulsions and is preceded by observable seizure activity.

Medullary haemorrhage (Option C): Medullary bleeding produces crossed motor and sensory signs, cranial nerve deficits, and vital center involvement.

questions.text: A 44-year-old bank clerk presents with a headache, nausea and ptosis of the left eye with blurred vision. She does not have fatigue of her eye movements. Examination revealed swelling on the left side of the face, proptosis and chemosis of the left eye, left mastoid swelling and left ophthalmoplegia involving cranial nerves. The pupil sizes were equal. A CT of her head is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A history of headache and no other obvious cause of ptosis is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis often follows infection (e.g., mastoiditis), presenting with headache, periorbital swelling, proptosis, chemosis, and involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, V1/2, and VI in the cavernous sinus.
  • Pupillary function remains intact early in CST, distinguishing it from third nerve palsy (which causes a dilated pupil) and Horner's syndrome (which causes miosis).
  • A CT head can be normal in early CST; MRI with MR venography is required to confirm the absence of flow in the cavernous sinus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Third nerve palsy (Option A): Causes isolated oculomotor deficits with pupil dilation, without proptosis, chemosis, or infectious signs.

Myasthenia gravis (Option B): Presents with fatigable ptosis and diplopia, spares proptosis and chemosis, and lacks signs of infection.

Pituitary tumour (Option C): Produces chronic headache and visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopia), not acute periorbital swelling or ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man is admitted with confusion over the last 3 days. He has a past medical history of hypertension and has had frequent falls in the past. Clinical examination is unremarkable. Which of these conditions needs to be excluded?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Subdural hematomas in the elderly often follow trivial head trauma. Rupture of bridging veins causes a slow venous bleed into the subdural space, presenting insidiously with altered mental status and minimal focal signs.
  • Risk factors such as hypertension and anticoagulant use increase bleeding propensity. The absence of significant neurological deficits despite confusion supports a subdural process rather than a large intracerebral haemorrhage.
  • Noncontrast head CT demonstrates a crescent-shaped hyperdense collection between the dura and brain surface, confirming the diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intracranial haemorrhage (Option A): Typically presents with acute focal neurological deficits (e.g., weakness, aphasia) rather than isolated confusion.

Meningitis (Option C): Would manifest with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and systemic signs of infection, not just confusion after minor falls.

Brain abscess (Option D): Presents subacutely with headache, fever, focal deficits, and elevated inflammatory markers; imaging shows a ring-enhancing lesion rather than a crescentic bleed.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is 30 weeks pregnant. She complains of a sudden-onset generalised headache. On examination, she has pupils that are reactive bilaterally, and there is a right-sided third nerve palsy. Which test is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A headache in a pregnant patient, with associated cranial nerve palsy, suggests cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). MR venography noninvasively visualises venous sinus occlusion (e.g., empty delta sign) without ionising radiation, making it the preferred diagnostic study in pregnant patients. Treatment consists of therapeutic anticoagulation with intravenous unfractionated heparin or subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin.

  • Venous sinus thrombosis of the lateral or sagittal sinus or of small cortical veins (cortical vein thrombosis) occurs as a complication of oral contraceptive use, pregnancy and the postpartum period, inflammatory bowel disease, intracranial infections (meningitis), dehydration and thrombophilias
  • Patients present with headache and may also have focal neurologic signs (especially paraparesis) and seizures.
  • Often, CT imaging is normal unless an intracranial venous haemorrhage has occurred, but the venous sinus occlusion is readily visualised using MR or CT venography
  • Intravenous heparin, regardless of the presence of intracranial haemorrhage, reduces morbidity and mortality, and the long-term outcome is generally good

Explanation of Other Options:

MR Angiography Brain (Option A): Visualises arterial circulation and will not detect venous sinus thrombosis.

MRI Brain plain (Option C): Routine MRI may miss sinus occlusion; dedicated venography sequences are required for diagnosis.

CT Head with contrast (Option D): Involves ionising radiation and is less sensitive than MRV for CVST; not ideal in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old lady presents to the hospital with an ataxic gait. On examination, the patient had difficulty standing without assistance, and minor movements of her head and body caused vertigo. There was mild postural tremor and marked hypotonia of the right limbs, mostly the arm. Finger-to-nose testing elicited marked intention tremor and dysdiadochokinesia in the right arm. Speech was dysarthric, but comprehension was good .Where is the lesion likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of ipsilateral limb hypotonia, intention tremor, dysdiadochokinesia, and limb ataxia localises the lesion to the cerebellar hemisphere, where coordination and fine motor control are mediated.
  • Cerebellar hemisphere lesions produce signs on the same side due to double-crossed pathways, explaining why right-sided findings indicate a right-sided lesion.
  • Absence of cranial nerve deficits or long-tract signs differentiates a pure cerebellar hemisphere lesion from brainstem (pons/medulla) pathology.

Explanation of Other Options:

Right pons (Option A): Pontine lesions cause ipsilateral cerebellar signs but are accompanied by cranial nerve deficits (e.g., facial weakness, abducens palsy).

Left medulla (Option B): Medullary lesions may produce ipsilateral ataxia but typically include nucleus ambiguus signs or ipsilateral tongue deviation.

Corpus callosum (Option D): Lesions here disrupt interhemispheric transfer, causing apraxia or alien hand phenomena, not cerebellar ataxia.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man has dysphasia and left-sided arm weakness. He is known to have hypertension, asthma and rheumatoid arthritis. In addition, he suffered from cluster headaches. He smokes 20 cigarettes a day. On examination, he has some weakness of the left hand. Visual fields, speech and sensation are normal. Blood pressure is 190/90 mmHg. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history suggests the dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome, one of the classic lacunar syndromes that are strokes in the subcortical regions (or brain stem) secondary to small vessel disease. The usual site of damage in the dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome is the internal capsule or pons.

  • Lacunar infarcts are small lesions (usually less than 1.5 cm in diameter) that occur in the distribution of short penetrating arterioles in the basal ganglia, pons, cerebellum, internal capsule, thalamus and, less commonly, the deep cerebral white matter.
  • Lacunar infarcts are associated with poorly controlled hypertension or diabetes and have been found in several clinical syndromes, including:
    1. Contralateral pure motor hemiparesis
    2. Contralateral pure hemisensory deficit
    3. Ipsilateral ataxia with hemiparesis
    4. Dysarthria clumsy hand syndrome

The neurologic deficit may progress over 24-36 hours before stabilizing.

Explanation of Other Options:

Partial posterior circulation infarct (Option A): Would present with brainstem or cerebellar signs (vertigo, ataxia, cranial nerve deficits) rather than isolated hand clumsiness.

Right pontine haemorrhage (Option C): Causes severe sudden deficits with altered consciousness and cranial nerve palsies, not a transient pure motor syndrome.

Total anterior circulation infarct (Option D): Involves cortical regions, producing global aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, and severe hemiparesis, which are absent.

questions.text: Infarctions secondary to low flow in the "watershed" between the distal PCA and MCA territories, as occurs after cardiac arrest, are seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bilateral visual association area lesions may result in Balint's syndrome, a disorder of the orderly visual scanning of the environment, usually resulting from infarctions secondary to low flow in the "watershed" between the distal PCA and MCA territories, as occurs after cardiac arrest.
  • Patients may experience persistence of a visual image for several minutes despite gazing at another scene (palinopsia) or an inability to synthesise the whole of an image (asimultagnosia).
  • Anton's syndrome occurs due to bilateral occlusion of the distal posterior cerebral arteries. It produces cortical blindness (blindness with preserved pupillary light reaction). The patient is often unaware of the blindness or may even deny it. (Option B)
  • Wallenberg's syndrome is lateral medullary syndrome, which occurs due to occlusion of the vertebral arteries. It results in acute onset ataxia, dizziness, Horner's syndrome and contralateral sensory loss. (Option C)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has subjectively diminished light touch and pinprick sensation in the left hand extending to above the elbow. Joint position sense is intact. He has difficulty distinguishing a cigarette from a pen using his right hand with his eyes closed. His two-point discrimination is 11 mm. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The postcentral gyrus, located in the anterior parietal lobe, is the primary somatosensory cortex. It processes crude touch and pain, so a lesion here causes contralateral loss of light touch and pinprick.
  • Two-point discrimination is a function of primary sensory cortex - an increased threshold (11 mm) indicates impaired cortical tactile processing in that region.
  • Stereognosis (object recognition by touch) requires intact primary somatosensory input. Astereognosis in the right hand localizes the lesion to the left anterior parietal cortex despite preserved joint position sense and absence of higher-order neglect, which rules out posterior parietal involvement.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior frontal (Option A): Lesions disrupt motor planning and executive functions, not primary sensory modalities or discrimination.

Posterior frontal (Option B): Involves the primary motor cortex, leading to contralateral weakness, not sensory deficits.

Posterior parietal (Option D): Association cortex lesions cause sensory inattention or neglect without loss of primary touch or altered two-point discrimination.

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady presents with a severe headache, which woke her up from sleep. She is not pregnant and was on no drugs. On examination, she was afebrile and alert. On examination of the optic fundus, the cup of the optic disc was filled, and the medial margins of the disc were blurred. There was no other CNS abnormality, in particular, no neck stiffness. A CT scan was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Superior sagittal sinus thrombosis impairs venous outflow, causing raised intracranial pressure manifesting as headache and papilledema despite a normal CT scan.

V Leiden mutation is found in around 20% of cases. Often there is a combination of causative factors: e.g. protein S deficiency and childbirth, pregnancy and Behcet's disease, OCP and factor V Leiden mutation.

  • A CT is often normal in VST; diagnosis requires MR venography
  • This is the most likely cause, despite not being pregnant or on the OCP. In only 10% of cases is cerebral venous thrombosis due to damage to the vessel wall by infection, tumour or trauma.
  • Commonest causes are inherited disorders of coagulation, of which factor with Venography

Explanation of Other Options:

Meningioma (Option A): presents often insidiously with symptoms depending on the location involved; CT may reveal a calcified extradural mass.

Benign intracranial hypertension (Option C): A typical presentation of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is that of a female of childbearing age who presents with headaches and is found to have papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

Migraine (Option D): presents with a unilateral throbbing headache with photophobia/phonophobia, which may be preceded by a visual aura; there are no features of raised intracranial tension.

questions.text: A 64 year old woman with headache and nausea is suspected of having posterior cerebral artery thrombosis. Which of the following is a recognised feature of this occurrence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe, and occlusion causes damage to the visual cortex, resulting in homonymous hemianopia.
  • In PCA strokes, visual symptoms predominate, while motor pathways (internal capsule) are spared, explaining the absence of hemiparesis.
  • Patients may also experience headache and nausea from increased intracranial pressure, but the hallmark is the visual field defect corresponding to the damaged cortical area.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cerebellar ataxia (Option A): Cerebellar signs occur in cerebellar artery infarcts, not PCA territory infarctions.

Hemiparesis (Option B): Motor weakness arises from anterior or middle cerebral artery infarcts affecting the motor cortex or internal capsule, not PCA lesions.

Third nerve palsy (Option D): Oculomotor nerve palsies are seen with posterior communicating artery aneurysms or midbrain lesions, not PCA thrombosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady presented to the Emergency Department with a diagnosis of DVT. She is in the third trimester of her first pregnancy, and she has been 'taking it easy' by resting a lot at home. In the department, she develops a right hemiparesis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cardiac abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a 'paradoxical embolus' where a right-sided thrombus has crossed into the arterial circulation.
  • The commonest cause is a patent foramen ovale. Although atrial septal defects are also a cause, they are rarer.
  • Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state through increased levels of clotting factors and reduced fibrinolysis, compounding DVT risk; when combined with a PFO, it significantly raises the likelihood of paradoxical embolism presenting as acute hemiparesis.
  • PFOs are often clinically silent until such events occur; transesophageal echocardiography with contrast (bubble study) is the diagnostic modality of choice to visualise right-to-left shunting and guide management decisions such as anticoagulation or percutaneous closure.

Explanation of Other Options:

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option A): Produces a persistent left-to-right shunt postnatally; paradoxical embolism only occurs in Eisenmenger physiology with pulmonary hypertension.

Primum atrial septal defect (Option C): Located adjacent to the AV valves, associated with endocardial cushion defects, and typically detected earlier due to volume overload symptoms.

Secundum atrial septal defect (Option D): True ASD in the fossa ovalis region; less common than PFO for paradoxical emboli and often presents with right-heart dilation rather than stroke.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with a two-month history of episodic loss of vision in her right eye. Her electrocardiogram was normal, and carotid ultrasound revealed a 49% stenosis of the right internal carotid artery, as assessed by the NASCAT criteria. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of aspirin and clopidogrel was found to prevent stroke following TIA better than aspirin alone in a large study(POINT STUDY).
  • Current NICE guidelines recommend that patients who have had a suspected TIA who are at high risk of a stroke (ABCD score of 4 or above) should have aspirin (300mg OD) started immediately. They also need specialist assessment and investigation within 24 hours of onset of symptoms. Secondary prevention measures should be introduced as soon as the diagnosis is confirmed, with consideration of individual risk factors.

The ABCD scoring system uses:

Age > or equal to 60 (1)

BP > or equal to 140/90mmHg at initial evaluation (1)

Clinical features (unilateral weakness 2, isolated speech disturbance 1, other 0)

Duration of symptoms (> or equal to 60 minutes, 10-59 minutes, <10 minutes)

Diabetes mellitus (1)

Although you cannot calculate the ABCD score with the information given in this question, aspirin remains the most appropriate answer.

Carotid Endarterectomy: (Option B)

  • Carotid endarterectomy has been established as an effective treatment for both symptomatic patients and asymptomatic patients who are shown to have carotid artery stenosis. It reduces the risk of disabling stroke or death by 48% in a person with severe symptomatic carotid stenosis (>70%) who has had a TIA. The peri-operative risk of disabling stroke or death is approximately 3%. Current guidelines recommend endarterectomy for symptomatic patients with greater than 70% stenosis, based on the North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial which showed clear benefit. The endarterectomy should be performed as soon as the patient is fit for surgery, preferably within two weeks of a TIA.
  • The benefit is marginal for symptomatic patients with 50-69% stenosis, but may be greater in male patients. NICE recommends these patients are also considered for endarterectomy. There is significantly less benefit for asymptomatic patients, even those with greater than 60% stenosis. Patients with less than 50% stenosis should not be considered for carotid surgery .
  • Recurrent stenosis can occur in 1-20% of patients following endarterectomy, and re-operation is needed in 1-3% of cases. Ipsilateral strokes occur in 9% of patients following endarterectomy, and 26% of those treated with medical management alone (within 2 years).
  • All patients with suspected non-disabling stroke or TIA who are considered as candidates for carotid endarterectomy should have carotid imaging within 1 week. If the patient has had a disabling stroke there is no real benefit in them undergoing the procedure.

Modified-release dipyridamole (Option C) is indicated in combination with aspirin only once a TIA has been confirmed by a specialist. Alone, it is recommended only if aspirin is contraindicated or not tolerated.

Clopidogrel (Option D) is recommended in patients who have had an ischaemic stroke, rather than a TIA.

Warfarin is only indicated for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis or if the patient has atrial fibrillation.

Please note that for this explanation, the North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET) criteria have been used. Carotid imaging reports will state which criteria are being used.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by a lesion of the occipital lobe?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The occipital lobe contains the primary visual cortex (V1) in the calcarine sulcus. Damage here abolishes conscious visual perception despite intact eyes, resulting in cortical blindness.

  • Lesions of the frontal lobeinclude difficulties with task sequencing and executive skills:
    • Expressive aphasia (receptive aphasias, a temporal lobe lesion)
    • Primitive reflexes
    • Perseveration (repeatedly asking the same question or performing the same task)
    • Anosmia
    • Personality changes.
  • Lesions of the parietal lobe include:
    • Apraxias (Option C)
    • Neglect
    • Astereognosis (unable to recognise an object by feeling it) (Option B)
    • Visual field defects (typically homonymous inferior quadrantanopia).
    • They may also cause acalculia (inability to perform mental arithmetic). (Option A)
  • Lesions of the temporal lobe cause:
    • Visual field defects (typically homonymous superior quadrantanopia)
    • Wernicke's (receptive) aphasia
    • Auditory agnosia
    • Memory impairment.
  • Occipital lobe lesions include:
    • Cortical blindness (blindness due to damage to the visual cortex, and may present as Anton syndrome, where there is blindness but the patient is unaware or denies blindness)
    • Homonymous hemianopia
    • Visual agnosia (seeing but not perceiving objects - it is different from neglect, since in agnosia the objects are seen and followed but cannot be named).

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman has had worsening shortness of breath for several years. She now has to sleep sitting up on two pillows. She has difficulty swallowing. There is no history of chest pain. She is afebrile. Recently, she suffered a stroke with left hemiparesis. A chest x-ray reveals a near-normal left ventricular size with a prominent left atrial border. Which of the following conditions is most likely to account for these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mitral valve stenosis leads to left atrial enlargement, but the left ventricle is usually small.
  • An enlarged left atrium may lead to pressure posteriorly on the oesophagus.
  • Chronic pulmonary venous hypertension from elevated left atrial pressure presents as orthopnea (requiring multiple pillows) and pulmonary congestion, while preserved LV size explains the near-normal ventricular silhouette.
  • Most mitral valvular disease in adults results from rheumatic heart disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic coarctation (Option A): Produces left ventricular hypertrophy and post-stenotic dilation, not isolated left atrial enlargement.

Cardiomyopathy (Option B): Dilated or hypertrophic cardiomyopathies manifest as ventricular chamber enlargement or thickening, not selective atrial border prominence.

Left renal artery stenosis (Option C): Causes secondary hypertension via renin-angiotensin activation; does not produce cardiac chamber enlargement on chest x-ray.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents with difficulty speaking. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He is currently on aspirin, simvastatin, amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, the patient is awake, and his blood pressure is 150/70 mmHg. His pulse is irregular. He has 4/5 strength on the right arm and leg and 5/5 strength on the left. When asked to point to the window, he appears unable to do so. When told to raise his arms and place his hands out, he does not. When visually shown the same action, he is able to perform it. When asked to repeat 'Today is a sunny day', he can do so. With what is this type of dysphasia consistent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transcortical sensory aphasia is what is described in this case. It is characterised by impaired auditory comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech, and is caused by damage to the temporal lobes. It differs from Wernicke's aphasia in that patients still have intact repetition and exhibit cholalia (the compulsive repetition of words). Improvement may be seen with speech therapy.
  • In Broca's or non-fluent or expressive aphasia, the patient is unable to name objects with poor comprehension and repetition. It localises to Broca's area in the left posterior inferior frontal gyrus. (Option A)
  • In Wernicke's or fluent or receptive aphasia the patient is able to form correct grammatical sentences but language content is incorrect. It localises to the dominant superior temporal gyrus. There is poor comprehension and repetition but verbal output is fluent.
  • In transcortical motor aphasia, which localises to the anterior superior frontal lobe, the patient has good comprehension and repetition but has halting, effortful speech. Patients also have impaired writing skills. (Option C)
  • Global aphasia results in an almost mute patient: there is poor verbal output, comprehension, repetition and understanding. (Option B)

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and multiple transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs) comes to the hospital complaining of visual field loss. He says this happened suddenly, and he woke up with problems with his vision the morning before coming to the Emergency department. Medications include clopidogrel, ramipril, atorvastatin, and metformin. On examination, his BP is 165/100 mmHg, his pulse is 76 and regular. Visual field examination reveals a right homonymous upper quadrantanopia. Where is the most likely site for the underlying lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Meyer's loop, the inferior optic radiations that loop through the temporal lobe, carry fibres from the contralateral superior visual field. A left temporal lobe lesion therefore, produces a right homonymous superior quadrantanopia "pie in the sky".

Temporal lobe infarcts from embolic or thrombotic events (common in diabetics and hypertensives) often present with quadrantanopia rather than full hemianopia, reflecting focal vascular territories.

Optic chiasmal lesions cause bitemporal hemianopia, and optic nerve lesions cause complete blindness in the affected eye. (Options C & D ruled out)

Occipital lobe lesions disrupt the primary visual cortex, causing complete homonymous hemianopia without quadrantic sparing, while parietal lobe radiation lesions produce inferior quadrantanopia. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Causes of a small pupil include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pontine haemorrhage disrupts descending sympathetic fibres in the pons, leading to unopposed parasympathetic activity and bilateral miosis (pinpoint pupils).
  • Interruption of the brainstem sympathetic outflow prevents normal pupillary dilation, causing small pupils despite ambient light changes.
  • In unconscious or critically ill patients, pinpoint pupils strongly suggest a pontine lesion, distinguishing it from peripheral or pharmacologic causes of miosis.

Causes of small pupils include:

  • Horner's syndrome
  • Old age
  • Pontine haemorrhage
  • Argyll Robertson pupil
  • Drugs and poisons (opiates, organophosphates).
  • Causes of dilated pupils include:
  • Holmes-Adie (myotonic) pupil
  • Third nerve palsy
  • Drugs and poisons (atropine, cobalt [CO], ethylene glycol).

Explanation of Other Options:

Carbon monoxide poisoning (Option A): Causes systemic hypoxia without directly affecting pupillary control, so pupils remain normal or dilated.

Ethylene glycol poisoning (Option B): Leads to metabolic acidosis and organ toxicity, but typically does not induce miosis.

Holmes-Adie pupil (Option C): Presents with a tonic, dilated pupil and slow light response due to ciliary ganglion damage, not constricted pupils.

questions.text: An 82-year-old male presented with acute right-sided weakness. Examination revealed minimal right facial weakness, impaired elevation of the right shoulder, with relatively preserved right hand strength. There was global weakness in the right leg, which appeared to be maximal in the foot. Which of the following arteries is most likely to have been affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The confusion could be due to middle or anterior artery circulation stroke, but the aim is to choose which is more likely.
  • Unilateral occlusion (distal to ant. comm. origin) of the anterior cerebral artery produces contralateral sensorimotor deficits mainly involving the lower extremity with relative sparing of face and hands (think of the homunculus).

The lateral lenticulostriate artery is a branch of the middle cerebral artery. Occlusion causes damage to the internal capsule, resulting in contralateral hemiparesis and sensory deficit. Speech may be affected (medial temporal lobe) as well as visual function (Meyer's loop: optic radiations affected).

Middle cerebral artery:

  • Occlusion at the stem (proximal segment) results in: Contralateral hemiplegia affecting face, arm, and leg (lesser) Homonymous hemianopia - ipsilateral head/eye deviation
  • If on the left: global aphasia.

Posterior cerebral artery:

A variety of neurological syndromes, including:

  • Pure hemisensory loss
  • Visual field loss- a variety
  • Visual agnosia
  • Disorders of reading (alexia, dyslexia).

choices.text: Computerised tomography (CT) of the brain is diagnostic
It is associated with an abnormality of the X chromosome

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding CADASIL (cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy) is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CADASIL is a diffuse disease of small arteries, predominantly in the brain.
  • It starts during mid-adulthood and is characterised by:
    • Recurrent ischaemic events (transient or permanent)
    • Attacks of migraine with aura
    • Severe mood disorders
    • Subcortical dementia and
    • A widespread leukoencephalopathy on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
  • Characteristic MRI changes include T2-weighted hyperintensity of the periventricular white matter.
  • CT is insensitive to the diffuse white-matter changes of CADASIL and is not diagnostic. (Option A ruled out)
  • A family history is almost always present; CADASIL is autosomal dominant due to a NOTCH3 mutation on chromosome 19, not X-linked. (Option C ruled out)
  • Infarcts are subcortical, and the thalami and basal gangliaare usually involved. (Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Optic chiasm lesions characteristically produce a bitemporal hemianopia
The physiological blind spot is unaffected by papilledema
In cortical blindness, pupillary reactions are abnormal
Optic tract lesions produce an ipsilateral homonymous hemianopia

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical considerations is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesions at the optic chiasm interrupt crossing nasal retinal fibres from both eyes, causing loss of temporal visual fields bilaterally - classic bitemporal hemianopia.

Common chiasmal lesions (e.g., pituitary adenomas) compress the central chiasm, selectively affecting decussating fibres and sparing uncrossed temporal fibres.

Papilledema enlarges the blind spot as swollen optic discs displace peripapillary photoreceptors. (Option B)

In cortical blindness, pupillary reflexes remain normal since the afferent and efferent arcs bypass the visual cortex. (Option C)

Optic tract lesions cause a contralateral homonymous hemianopia due to interruption of post-chiasmal fibres. (Option D)

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department after collapsing following a cricket match in his village. He was hit on the head with the ball whilst batting, but got up afterwards. During the following 30 minutes, he became increasingly confused, drowsy and then unresponsive, slumped in a chair. On examination, his BP is elevated at 180/110 mmHg, with a pulse of 58. His GCS is 6. He is intubated and ventilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic "lucid interval" followed by rapid decline in consciousness, hypertension, and bradycardia (Cushing's response) indicates an extradural haemorrhage with raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • IV mannitol is the first-line osmotic agent. It draws water out of the swollen brain tissue into the bloodstream, lowering ICP and improving cerebral perfusion.
  • While preparing for surgical evacuation, controlled hyperventilation can further reduce ICP temporarily by inducing cerebral vasoconstriction.

Explanation of Other Options:

IV alteplase (Option A): Thrombolytic therapy is indicated for ischaemic stroke, not intracranial haemorrhage, and would worsen bleeding.

IV furosemide (Option B): Loop diuretics reduce systemic fluid but have a delayed and less effective impact on ICP compared to osmotic agents like mannitol.

IV heparin (Option C): Anticoagulation is contraindicated in suspected intracranial bleeding, as it would exacerbate haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents with difficulty speaking. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He is currently on aspirin, simvastatin, amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, the patient is awake, and his blood pressure is 150/70 mmHg. His pulse is irregular. He has 4/5 strength in the right arm and leg and 5/5 strength on the left. When asked to point to the window, he does this correctly. When told to raise his arms and place his hands out, he is seen to have a pronator drift on the right. He is shown a pen and asked what it is. He is unable to identify it by name. He is asked to use it appropriately and begins to write on a piece of paper. When asked to repeat 'Today is a sunny day', he can do so. What type of dysphasia is this consistent with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anomic aphasia presents with fluent speech, intact comprehension, and preserved repetition, but a specific inability to find and produce the correct names for objects (naming difficulty) despite knowing their use.
  • The patient's fluent output and perfect repetition alongside isolated naming failure pinpoint damage to the language network where lexical retrieval occurs, without involvement of Broca's or Wernicke's areas.
  • Writing and functional use of the object remain intact because motor and semantic association areas are unaffected, distinguishing anomic aphasia from other aphasia types.
  • In Broca's or non-fluent or expressive aphasia, the patient is unable to name objects with poor comprehension and repetition. It localises to Broca's area in the left posterior inferior frontal gyrus. (Option B)
  • An injury to the anterior superior frontal lobe results in transcortical motor aphasia with good comprehension but poor verbal output, with the exception of echolalia or repetition. Writing is usually also impaired. Repetition is also spared as the arcuate fasciculus is not involved. (Option D)
  • Conduction aphasia has poor repetition and naming but intact comprehension and fluent verbal output. It is different to the transcortical sensory and motor aphasias in that there is intact comprehension and fluency, which are not seen in each of the transcortical aphasias, respectively. (Option C)

"+" = relatively intact function, "-" = impaired function, "±" = mild or equivocal impairment

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department following a witnessed first-ever seizure. She is drowsy and confused postictally. A CT brain shows petechial haemorrhages in the right hemisphere. An MRI shows cerebral venous sinus thrombosis. Which of the following would be the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is more common in young women.
  • It may present with headaches or symptoms of raised intracranial pressure. It can cause seizures.
  • Mechanism: Thrombosis of dural venous sinuses or cortical veins → impaired venous drainage → ↑ venous pressure → blood-brain barrier breakdown → vasogenic oedema and petechial/hemorrhagic infarction.
  • CT venography (CTV) / MR venography (MRV): Gold standard to demonstrate filling defects/absence of flow in affected sinuses (e.g., "empty delta sign" on contrast CT).
  • The underlying problem is a thrombosis, and the petechial haemorrhages are caused by venous outflow blockage. It is therefore important that anticoagulation is started immediately to relieve the cause.
  • Heparin is the most appropriate anticoagulant to use in this circumstance.

Explanation of Other Options:

Antibiotics (Option A): Antimicrobials are indicated for septic thrombosis but are not appropriate in non-infectious CVST without evidence of infection.

Aspirin (Option B): Antiplatelet agents have no proven benefit in venous thrombosis and do not address the underlying coagulation cascade in CVST.

Supportive management (Option D): Supportive measures alone fail to resolve the thrombus; withholding anticoagulation is associated with worse outcomes and higher complication rates.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presented with an acute, severe occipital headache, unsteadiness of her gait and vomiting. She had a history of poorly controlled hypertension. On examination, there was nystagmus to the left, ataxia of the left limbs and gait ataxia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sudden occipital headache with severe nausea, vomiting, and ipsilateral cerebellar signs (nystagmus, limb/gait ataxia) is classic for a hypertensive intracerebellar bleed.
  • The posterior fossa is a confined space; even small haemorrhages rapidly increase intracranial pressure, leading to brainstem compression and potential herniation - patients can become comatose within hours.
  • Prominent ataxia and vomiting distinguish cerebellar haemorrhage from other intracranial bleeds.

Explanation of Other Options:

Basal ganglia haemorrhage (Option B): Contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, or hemi-inattention. Aphasia, especially non-fluency and impaired comprehension, is frequently seen if a haemorrhage occurs in the posterior limb of the left internal capsule.

Pontine haemorrhage (Option C): There are numerous nuclei located within the pons. Rapidly deteriorating level of consciousness, impaired extraocular movement and extensive sensorimotor deficits are clinical clues to pontine haemorrhage.

Subdural haemorrhage (Option D): Usually has a more gradual onset after trauma, with a crescent-shaped bleed on CT and progressive headache or confusion, not the acute cerebellar syndrome described.

choices.text: Prior treatment with intravenous tPA for acute stroke 1 year ago

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to treatment with intravenous tPA (tissue plasminogen activator) in a patient with an acute ischemic stroke?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A history of intracerebral haemorrhage at any time is an absolute contraindication to IV tPA due to the high risk of precipitating life-threatening rebleeding in previously damaged brain tissue.

Previous thrombolysis beyond the 3-month window does not increase bleeding risk enough to contraindicate repeat treatment.

Blood pressure 170/85 mm Hg falls below the 185/110 mm Hg threshold and is acceptable for tPA initiation.

Remote stroke (>3 months) is not a contraindication once the acute period has passed.

Contraindications for thrombolysis:

  • Significant head trauma or prior stroke in the previous 3 months
  • Symptoms suggest subarachnoid haemorrhage
  • Arterial puncture at a noncompressible site in the previous 7 days
  • History of previous intracranial haemorrhage, Intracranial neoplasm, arteriovenous malformation, or aneurysm
  • Recent intracranial or intraspinal surgery
  • Elevated blood pressure (systolic >185 mm Hg or diastolic >110 mm Hg)
  • Active internal bleeding
  • Acute bleeding diathesis, including but not limited to Platelet count <100,000/μL Heparin received within 48 hours, resulting in aPTT greater than the upper limit of normal Current use of anticoagulant with INR >1.7 or PT >15 seconds Current use of direct thrombin inhibitors or direct factor Xa inhibitors with elevated sensitive laboratory tests (such as aPTT, INR, platelet count, and ECT; TT; or appropriate factor Xa activity assays)
  • Blood glucoseconcentration <50 mg/dL (2.7 mmol/L)
  • CT demonstrates multilobar infarction (hypodensity > 1 3 cerebral hemisphere)

Inclusion Criteria for thrombolysis in stroke:

  • Diagnosis of ischemic stroke causing a measurable neurological deficit
  • Onset of symptoms <3 hours before beginning treatment
  • Aged ≥18 years

questions.text: Which of the following antiplatelet agents has been proven effective in the acute treatment of ischemic stroke?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aspirin is the only antiplatelet agent that has been proven to be effective for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke.
  • Mechanism & evidence: Aspirin irreversibly inhibits platelet cyclooxygenase-1, reducing thromboxane A-mediated aggregation. Large trials (CAST, IST) demonstrated that early aspirin (within 48 hours of stroke onset) lowers recurrent stroke risk and mortality.
  • Dosage & timing: A loading dose of 150-300 mg as soon as haemorrhage is excluded, followed by 75-100 mg daily, is recommended to maximise early benefit.
  • Safety profile: Aspirin's favourable bleeding profile and proven benefit make it the cornerstone of acute ischaemic stroke management.

Explanation of Other Options:

Clopidogrel (Option B): Used for long-term secondary prevention, especially in aspirin-intolerant patients, but lacks robust evidence as monotherapy in the acute post-stroke period.

Dipyridamole (Option C): Extended-release dipyridamole plus aspirin reduces long-term recurrence (ESPS-2), but is not indicated for initial acute treatment.

Prasugrel (Option D): Approved for acute coronary syndromes and PCI. Not studied in stroke and carries a higher bleeding risk, making it unsuitable acutely.

questions.text: All are true about Weber syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Weber syndrome is characterised by damage to the cerebral peduncle.

This leads to damage to the corticospinal pathway and the oculomotor nerve.

Hence, the patient will develop ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia.

The blood vessels compromised are the paramedian branches of upper basilar and proximal posterior cerebral arteries.

Dorsal midbrain syndrome is Parinaud syndrome/ Supranuclear vertical gaze disorder caused by damage to the posterior commissure.

It is characterised by:

  • Loss of up-gaze
  • Sun setting sign
  • Convergence retraction nystagmus
  • Lid retraction
  • Skew deviation
  • Pseudo-abducens palsy
  • Light near dissociation of pupils

questions.text: A 63-year-old diabetic woman develops weakness in the left side of her face, right arm and right leg. She also has diplopia on left lateral gaze. What is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has weakness in the left side of the face, and arm and leg weakness on the right side. This is called crossed hemiplegia and is characteristically seen with pontine stroke.
  • The damage to the same side 6th and 7th cranial nerve can explain facial weakness and diplopia on looking to the left.
  • The corticospinal tract damage in the pons will lead to contralateral spastic weakness in arms and legs.

Explanation of Other Options:

Right pons (Option A): Would cause right facial paralysis with left-sided limb weakness, opposite the presentation.

Right midbrain (Option B): Affects oculomotor (III) nerve and red nucleus, leading to oculomotor palsy and contralateral ataxia or tremor, not facial weakness with abducens palsy.

Left midbrain (Option D): Produces ipsilateral oculomotor palsy (ptosis, "down-and-out" eye) and contralateral hemiparesis but spares the facial nerve and abducens nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following is preserved in a locked-in state?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Locked-in syndrome results from ventral pontine infarction, destroying bilateral corticospinal tracts and corticobulbar fibres
  • The vertical gaze centre in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (dorsal midbrain) remains intact.
  • It occurs secondary to basilar artery thrombosis.
  • Bilateral corticospinal damage leads to Quadriplegia
  • Bilateral corticobulbar damage to the 3rd, 4th, 6th and 7th nerves leads to loss of horizontal gaze, facial diplegia. (Option A)
  • Bilateral corticobulbar damage to nerves leads to aphonia and tongue paralysis. (Option B)
  • Voluntary modulation of diaphragmatic contraction via corticospinal pathways is impaired, so respiratory effort becomes purely reflexive. (Option D)
